key_points: U.S. President Joe Biden visited Louisiana to assess Hurricane Ida's damage following the storm's devastation.
The visit included meetings with Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards and local officials to discuss the hurricane's impact.
Hurricane Ida left one million people without power and another 600,000 without water in Louisiana.
Ida is the fifth most powerful hurricane to hit the United States, causing extensive damage and power outages.
The death toll from Hurricane Ida includes at least nine in Louisiana and at least 46 along the East Coast.
Power restoration efforts in Louisiana reduced the number of homes and businesses without power to around 823,000.
New Jersey's death toll from Ida's impacts rose to 25, with at least six people still missing.
Biden toured damage in Louisiana communities such as LaPlace and emphasized the need for infrastructure improvements.
Biden's infrastructure plan includes investments in burying power lines underground to prevent future outages.
Biden approved an emergency declaration for New Jersey and New York, providing federal assistance for response efforts.
